abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the General Education
            Project for Sri Lanka was satisfactory. The project achieved
            most of its objectives, its impact on institutional
            development has been partially successful, sustainability is
            likely, and the performance of both the Bank and Borrower
            was satisfactory. Several lessons can be learned from this
            project. First, there is a need for the Government to
            address the lengthy period required to staff new project
            implementation units. Second, clearer follow-up procedures
            to address key policy recommendations of the National
            Education Commission and studies need to be
            institutionalized. Third, the membership of tender
            committees needs to be further standardized by MEHE to
            reduce the numerous and lengthy reviews and speed up the
            procurement process. Fourth, joint efforts by GOSL and IDA
            to standardize the content of progress reports should be
            continued. Fifth, project performance and sustainability
            increased when the operational unit responsible for
            continuation of the activities was given implementation
            responsibilities. Sixth, future investments in the education
            sector should be based on clearly defined criteria and
            measures to assess the impact of these inputs should be
            developed. Finally, when IDA identifies a task manager
            appropriately and gives the task manager sufficient
            authority and resources to address policy and implementation
            issues, increased consistency occurs and the implementation
            of a project improves.
